hug.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to put your arms around someone and hold them tightly to show love or friendship
hug.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: We stood there crying and hugging each other.
She went to her daughter and hugged her tightly.
hug.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to put your arms around yourself
hug.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: Sarah sat on the floor, hugging her knees.
She stood hugging herself against the cold.
hug.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to move along the side, edge, top etc of something, staying very close to it
hug.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: The small boats hugged the coast.
hug.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: if clothes hug your body, they fit closely
hug.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to hold something in your arms close to your chest
hug.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: He was hugging a big pile of books.
Hug is a reciprocal verb This type of verb is used when saying that two or more people or things do something that involves both or all of them It does not need to have an object  In this sentence, hug is intransitive and does not have an object
In these sentences, hug is transitive
She and her friend hugged each other
hug.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: to put your arms around someone and hold them tightly to show love or friendship
Mother hugged him and tucked him into bed.
Come here and give me a big hug.
to put your arms around someone and hold him or her in a caring way. Embrace is more formal than hug
The two leaders embraced each other.
to put your arms around someone or something as a sign of love, especially a child or a small animal
She sat on a chair, cuddling her daughter.
to hold someone closely to your body, especially to comfort them or show that you love them
The woman put her arms around the sobbing boy.
to hold someone very gently in your arms, like you would hold a baby
She held the baby in her arms.
She cradled his head in her hands and kissed him on the forehead
